text: before we jump into this scishow talk
show with dr. Rebecca Richards quartum
one of this year's MacArthur Genius
fellows we wanted to thank the MacArthur
Foundation for helping set up this
interview with us we also want to thank
Bill and Melinda Gates every year they
put out an annual letter focusing on
ways to fight extreme poverty and poor
health around the world this year's
letter comes out this week and focuses
on investing in technology that can save
children under five who are dying of
curable illnesses in talking to Rebecca
Richards quartum we realized that her
work embodies this mission and wanted to
share this video the same week that that
letter comes out you can learn more
about Bill and Melinda Gates his annual
letter and the MacArthur Foundation in
the description below please check them
out hello there welcome to the scishow
talk show times where I Hank green
talked to some interesting person in the
world about something interesting this
is Rebecca Richards quartum a professor
at Rice University the reason we're
talking to you is that you just got the
MacArthur Genius grant so you have
officially been bestowed a genius this
is as far as I can tell the only way
that you get to decide that you are
objectively a genius so congratulations
and thank you for joining us and you
know how does it feel to be an official
genius it's it's obviously it's a huge
honor to get recognized as by the
MacArthur Foundation I don't know that I
love the genius title it's really it's
so wonderful to have the recognition and
the platform that comes with that
fellowship but most especially to have
access to unrestricted resources that we
can use to try and continue our work
improving health for women and children
and sub-saharan Africa so when you say
unrestricted resources you mean that's
just an unlimited amount of money I wish
it was an unlimited amount of money so
the fellowship comes with six hundred
and twenty five thousand dollars over
five years but there's absolutely no
strings on how you use it
and so we can do whatever we think will
be most helpful and then research there
often is strings that come along with
grant money absolutely it's normally let
me get grant money we write a proposal
that specifies how we'll use those
dollars and you know you just you have
less efforts you need to be creative and
invent
even try things that you're not sure
will work but if they did work it could
be really exciting yeah
and just most more opportunity for
innovation changing your path halfway
through so what was the work that you
think led to to you getting this grant
we've been working over the last ten
years to really try and improve health
for babies in places like Malawi which
is a small country in sub-saharan Africa
and you know just sort of put it in
perspective if you look at the rates of
a newborn death and Malawi it's really
similar to what existed here in Texas
more than a hundred years ago so you
know babies are dying of conditions that
we absolutely know how to prevent and
places like Houston and and all over
high-income countries and so we've been
working to try and build technologies
that are affordable and that are rugged
and robust to work in those environments
and we've had some success it's been
really exciting to see over the last
couple of years some of these coming to
scale mm-hmm so you know I think in part
it was a recognition that this approach
can work and at a belief that it should
be expanded so I'm very interested in
medicine and the cost of medicine and
obviously we have a good healthcare
system here in the US there's things to
complain about but let's be honest but
like if you look at you know if there's
a premature baby and you look at the
amount of money that goes into the
equipment that is going to help keep
that baby alive is gonna help keep that
baby healthy you're looking at a big
price tag what do you think is the
difference between you know like a CPAP
machine that we create for a baby here
in the US that might cost I don't I have
no idea but I'm guessing in the tens of
thousands of dollars at least and like
how do like figuring out how to make
that accessible it get like usable make
it inexpensive it isn't necessarily a
priority here and that can make it so
that it becomes a like a technology that
is not available to people who need it
how do you think about like making that
technology for a different market so I
always think for me really the aha
moment was when I went to Malawi and I
visited first the newborn intensive care
unit and what I saw was you know
somewhere on the order of 60 babies and
just two or three nurses we're doing
everything they could to take care of
them with very little equipment and then
on that same tour just literally down
the hall from that intensive care ward
that had no functional equipment there
was this entire room that was full of
equipment that people from places like
Houston had donated intending to try and
help improve care there but when that
equipment got there it broke very
quickly because maybe the line voltage
spiked or the air was dusty and so the
air filter got clogged or they couldn't
get the consumables that they needed and
so for me that was when I realized that
it's not just that we need the places
like Malawi need more of what we have
they really need a different kind of
technology mm-hmm you have to put the
focus on making it affordable and making
it rugged or it's not going to last
interesting yeah so we really tried to
take that we call it through bold
innovation take that frugal innovation
approach and apply it broadly across
healthcare needs so so you're looking at
creating all sorts of equipment with
that with that focus in mind like can
you walk me through a little bit of the
like you know testing phase innovation
phase engineering phase and then also
I'm very interested in like actually
scaling it up and producing these
products yeah so you know I tell my
students all the time and I think the
process starts with listening mm-hmm and
I think you need to listen to people who
are in the setting where the technology
is going to be used and listen to what
is it that they say they need to be able
to do their job more effectively if you
don't do that I think you're not going
to design the right thing mm-hmm
in the process ends with scaling and
again I tell my students if it doesn't
leave your lab
it isn't really innovation so what
happens in between is how do we go
through the brainstorming process of
coming up with concepts that could work
there we test them first in a laboratory
then test them usually a healthcare
healthcare settings in a high-income
country so we'll often test them here in
Houston in a Texas Medical Center to be
sure that they deliver the right kind of
therapeutic effect then we'll go to a
place like Malawi and do an actual
clinical evaluation with the appropriate
ethical approvals and then you turn that
that prototype you be going to turn it
into a product working with the private
side okay so that's that's a multi-year
process I would imagine like there's a
lot like there's a lot from design and
then you have to take it into the field
and see how it's going to function it's
like I can give you an example so our
CPAP device for example which is
designed to how premature babies breathe
that was a need that came to us in the
summer of 2009 we had a prototype by the
spring of 2010 got a lot of feedback and
improved it and then we took it in a
clinical evaluation in early 2012 it
just became a product with international
regulatory approval and now it's being
used in 23 countries so from 2009 to now
almost 2017 that's how long it took to
go to somebody said this so we really
need to now you can actually buy it and
that's not a terrible considering that
you're dealing with government
regulations international regulations
you're dealing with you know testing a
product in one place and testing it and
across the world I mean I guess I would
say it's not a terribly long time on the
one hand on the other there a way to
speed it up yeah that's like yeah when
you go to Malawi you know I thought
normally four times a year and you go
into the newborn unit and you see every
single trip babies that need this mm-hmm
feels like a long time it's like a long
time and we are as it you know we are
getting much better
at at innovating and rapidly prototyping
and developing technology you know you
like it's kind of remarkable that it
would take you know how long does it
take to develop a new mobile phone in
China like on the order of months these
days and that mobile phone is just a
tremendously complicated much more
complicated than a CPAP machine and of
course like there's a lot of mobile
phone development infrastructure in the
world and not a lot of like rugged
inexpensive CPAP infrastructure but but
how how can we how can we speed that up
is it the regulations that are slowing
you down is it the manufacturing process
is it the testing process so you know I
think that this is an area where there's
there's an important need for funding or
the development of these technologies
but then I think even a more important
need to think about how do we guarantee
that there's an actual market and
purchased them and you know there
there's no question that there's a huge
amount of need for these devices I can
go to any hospital in the developing
world almost any hospital in the
developing world and there's a need from
many many technologies that doesn't
necessarily mean there's somebody who
can write a check to purchase those
technologies if they're available on the
market and so you know I think one of
the things that's really interesting for
medical devices is to look at what the
international community did for vaccines
for vaccines we have the Global Alliance
for vaccines and immunization gobby and
it basically guaranteed financing so
that manufacturers knew that if they
made these vaccines and it helped
forecast demand and and it helps
countries make a plan or getting access
and then ultimately transitioning to
paying or on their own don't really have
that in the medical device area I think
it's a really important yeah yeah that's
that's a fascinating point that you know
you talk about like this roomful of
machines and like who knows how many of
your see paps can be bought with one of
the ones that was donated it but but
donations are often machines that have
you know I've have been used previously
and then you're donating you're getting
tax write-off like there's all kinds of
reasons to donate an expensive piece of
medical machinery and sort of less
reason to just develop a market which is
the thing that is actually needed like
we need people in like an ideal world
you you need that hospital to be able to
fund itself and to buy its own rugged
and expensive medical devices but it's
nice that we have them the model of the
of the vaccine success to maybe go after
that with with medical devices yeah I
think there's some other interesting
opportunities where where technology can
be used both in a place like Malawi and
in a place like the US so you have a
dual market use then I think you have
some really interesting opportunities so
for example we're working on a really
simple way to measure bilirubin and the
blood to know if babies suffer from
newborn jaundice and we've been
developing that in partnership with
pediatricians in Malawi and
pediatricians in Houston and they
actually both want the test and it's
finally available and so I think that's
a really interesting opportunity because
there's the potential to use a market
and a high resource setting to support
in some way as the markets and low
resource settings but not everything
fits that model right right I mean and
my non-science just frustrated with
American health care models is aware
that there is not a lot of market
pressure to make things cheaper in the
US you know we have a weird system that
that just sort of is like well you know
like let's just have the best possible

how much it costs but if there is a
market pressure for cost somewhere else
maybe that inspires us and activates us
to innovate for a lower cost product
that we could then turn around and use
to disrupt some of the existing more
expensive technologies here in the US
it's a really interesting way to think
about reverse innovation that something
works as effectively is more expensive
things then why not so
you say that you take the product of the

being like we have this design we think

partnered with industrial design firms
so sometimes we say in our program we
make ugly stuff but it works yeah you
know it performs the function that you

we'll do is we will work with an

manufactured in a cost-effective way
but to make it look like a real medical
device to improve its usability right
home and you know I think it's really
important you don't nurses and

use something that looks like a student

real medical device and it should so
we've had great luck working with

just like plug this baby into this

she's really an engineer at heart so she

mm-hmm that caused it to overheat so
then she had to set up a kitchen band
next to it like a bit cool and it
actually it worked what everybody afraid
to use it
because yeah that's that's very cool
though so then for the next stage where

international regulatory approval well
we have chosen to do in our program as
we've identified people that want to

our philosophy as a program is that we

they're based in in the Bay Area and
they took it through international

the first prototypes and you know I

been working so hard on side by side
